image.altText: Machinery inside a steel factory with little lighting

props.synopsis: New details about the state of the Whyalla steelworks were revealed in a legal document this week. Here's what we learned.

title.children: Why a Whyalla steelworks snapshot reveals 'more than we anticipated'

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas speaking and gesturing his hand on stage to a crowd

props.synopsis: South Australian voters resonated with Labor's pledge to "fix the ramping crisis", among other promises, but could it come back to bite them in next year's election? State political reporter Leah MacLennan explains.

title.children: Is the SA government on track to meet all its promises?

image.altText: A beach with a dune and ocean

props.synopsis: An Eyre Peninsula community reeling from two fatal shark attacks in 15 months is concerned that recreational fishing and cage diving could be attracting sharks to the area.

title.children: Fishing restrictions considered after report examining fatal SA shark attacks

image.altText: Soursob Bob at Milledge's Distillation

props.synopsis: Milledge's Distillation in the heart of Port Adelaide's commercial district is being taken to court by the local council over what its owners say is a lone noise complaint.

title.children: Popular Adelaide music venue fears closure over single noise complaint

image.altText: A man wearing a T-shirt crossing his arms in front of a bay with seaweed and cliffs

props.synopsis: Similar seawater quality problems to those that have been reported near Victor Harbor are threatening the livelihood of a fisher in the state's south-east.

title.children: SA fisher says 'burning' water harming marine life and business

image.altText: A man in a suit walks down court steps in front of other people

props.synopsis: A man who pretended to be a nurse at one of Adelaide's major hospitals has shown "limited insight" into his offending and has a "narcissistic component" to his personality, a court hears.

title.children: Nurse impersonator's apology leaves magistrate 'somewhat troubled'

image.altText: A firefighting volunteer wearing a fedora hat

props.synopsis: Volunteer firefighters and their support staff have travelled more than 1,000 kilometres to help small towns fighting fires in South Australia's south-east.

title.children: Tents, mates, and big breakfasts for travelling volunteers helping firies

image.altText: A teenager with blonde hair looks forward whilst a man hold a mirror to show the haircut from the back of his head.

props.synopsis: Young barbers are setting up shop in smaller regional communities, with their success fuelled by social media.

title.children: Country style on trend as TikTok helps young barbers draw clients

image.altText: James Bull with his hand in the air as he does a DJ set

props.synopsis: People with disabilities are sometimes turned away from regular nightclubs, where they can be falsely accused of being drunk or made uncomfortable by strobe lighting — but The Heart Beat Club is run by DJs with disabilities, for people with disabilities.

title.children: DJs to spin their way into hearts of Fringe-goers on disability club night

image.altText: A woman with a tube in her nose and in a hospital bed.

props.synopsis: SA women with endometriosis are experiencing long delays in diagnosis and treatment because of problems accessing medical services, as well as a lack of awareness, a parliamentary inquiry finds.

title.children: Endometriosis sufferers experiencing delays in SA for treatment and diagnosis

image.altText: A smiling woman wearing a yellow top stands in front of a field of yellow flowers

props.synopsis: A mother charged with the attempted murder of her two sons after stabbing them multiple times on an Adelaide motorway has been found not guilty by way of mental incompetence.

title.children: Mother who stabbed her two sons found not guilty by way of mental incompetence

image.altText: A state MP surrounded by journalists outside court.

props.synopsis: Fraud and theft offending by a South Australian MP was fuelled by "greed" and has so far cost him his family home and more than $800,000 in legal fees, a court hears.

title.children: Fraudster MP who stole more than $430k motivated by 'greed', court told

image.altText: A view of the Royal Adelaide Hospital.

props.synopsis: Doctors and nurses say patient care could be compromised if the SA government pushes ahead with plans to shift the infectious diseases unit out of Adelaide’s biggest public hospital and move it to a site across the road.

title.children: Hospital 'Tetris puzzle' could put SA patients at risk, tribunal hears

image.altText: A man stands in front of a white wall in american prison

props.synopsis: Former Adelaide megachurch pastor Daniel Menelaou, who was last week charged in the US with possession of child sexual abuse material, has been banned from working with children in SA.

title.children: Pastor arrested in US for alleged abuse banned from working with children

image.altText: Trucks and car travelling along a major road

props.synopsis: Community calls for a full duplication of the Sturt Highway have been back by South Australia's peak motoring body, which says planning needs to start now for the project to be realised.

title.children: Business owner's pre-election plea for highway duplication and safety

image.altText: Keicha Day looking at the camera. She has multiple lines of light paint on her face. Her expression is determined.

props.synopsis: Australia has a painful past. For the first time, the country has been grappling with recording the stories of that history in a truth-telling commission.

title.children: These crimes were hidden for generations. Now Australia's having a moment of truth

image.altText: A man in a navy blue suit, white shirt and blue tie with short grey hair smiles at the camera

props.synopsis: Struggling to gain traction at home after taking the top job, UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer's performance on the international stage has been received differently.

title.children: Keir Starmer was struggling in the polls. Then he met Donald Trump

image.altText: A close-up of Donald Trump's face.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump's attacks on the judiciary pre-election, as he personally fought criminal prosecution, was one thing. But the way it's escalating from the White House is stress-testing the separation of powers.

title.children: President vs judge: Deportations test Donald Trump's respect for law

image.altText: Sleeping woman

props.synopsis: The days are starting to get a little bit cooler, which means daylight saving time will soon be ending in the jurisdictions that observe it. But there are still two weeks until the clocks change.

title.children: There's still another fortnight of daylight saving time. Here's why

image.altText: A plume of smoke rising from a hill with houses on it in Lebanon

props.synopsis: Israel strikes Lebanon in retaliation for rockets targeting Israel, killing two, including a child, in the heaviest exchange of fire since the ceasefire with the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah.

title.children: Israel strikes Lebanon in response to cross-border rocket fire

image.altText: A woman with her arms resting over a balcony railing.

props.synopsis: A short walk from the heart of Lismore are a bunch of homes among the gum trees on a dead end road called Pine Street. They call it a community, but the law calls it illegal.

title.children: Lismore squatters remain defiant in the face of the government's demolition threats

image.altText: Dark clouds over Brisbane.

props.synopsis: Experts say infrastructure in south-east Queensland and northern New South Wales needs to be built to withstand cyclones.

title.children: Ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred a 'dress rehearsal' for events to come

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaking at a podium.

props.synopsis: The leader of the federal Liberal Party is making some big announcements, including plans to sack thousands of public servants. It is 1951.

title.children: Who came up with the idea to cut thousands of public service jobs?

image.altText: Torsos of two people in police uniforms, with a focus on a holstered taser on one person's uniform.

props.synopsis: Concerns have been raised about the bail process for NSW Police officers charged with domestic violence-related offences, with a former magistrate saying the decision should be made independently of police.

title.children: Fears for DV victims as accused police officers granted bail by colleagues

image.altText: A woman in a tiara sits in the back of a car with a man in full military uniform

props.synopsis: At the age of 24, a brash and fiery Princess Anne was called "her royal rudeness" by the British tabloids. But when a man brandishing two guns tried to kidnap her outside Buckingham Palace, Anne's sharp tongue helped save her life.

title.children: How a fiery Princess Anne talked her way out of being kidnapped in 1974

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: A photo of a capsized boat with people on its head

props.synopsis: The boat was carrying 13 people, including 11 Australian tourists, when it capsized in rough seas off Bali.

title.children: Australian woman killed as snorkelling boat capsizes off Bali

image.altText: A brown spirit being poured over ice in a glass tumbler.

props.synopsis: Rum distillers are taking over a 1940s milk factory in the Hunter Valley, as the industry looks to go large in the international market.

title.children: Rum makers take over historic milk factory as Aussie spirits go global

image.altText: A woman on a balcony with a sunset behind her smiling

props.synopsis: Psychologists say a ritual or celebration can help a person move forward from a difficult phase of their life.

title.children: 'Shedding the past': How celebrating her divorce helped Leigh move on

image.altText: Grey beard man wearing white t-shirt and cowboy hat, leaning against fence, dam behind

props.synopsis: A property owner who wants to open his share of "God's country" to tourists says he is excited to get started after a lengthy and expensive legal fight to build an eco-resort.

title.children: Tiny homes boss ordered to plant 20,000 seedlings in eco-resort trade-off

image.altText: Tom Gleeson stands at a podium with the Hard Quiz sign to his left.

props.synopsis: You just couldn't stay away, could you? Let's see how poorly you do this week. It’s time to play, HARD!

title.children: Think you're smart? Show us what you've got

image.altText: A waitrees looks to the side as she holds a cup of coffee balanced on a saucer

props.synopsis: An expansion to the ACT's portable long service leave scheme, which allows those in casual or insecure work to access the entitlement even if they switch employers, is being put on hold amid the ongoing cost-of-living crisis.

title.children: 'Tough time' for businesses delays expansion of ACT leave scheme

image.altText: A woman with a blonde bob smiles in her kitchen while showing off a jar of pickled carrot peels

props.synopsis: Rebecca Buckley is getting creative to keep food on the table amid skyrocketing expenses. As more people face food insecurity in the cost-of-living crisis, researchers warn it can lead to disordered eating.

title.children: Rebecca went from survival mode to self-care when facing food insecurity

image.altText: A man in a kayak holds onto a hot air balloon.

props.synopsis: During the Canberra Balloon Spectacular, pilot Justin Galbraith bounces the basket of his hot air balloon across the surface of Lake Burley Griffin and throws out a towline to pull along hundreds of kayakers and paddle-boarders in his wake.

title.children: Hot air balloons tow kayakers and boarders in 'world's slowest water sport'
